adjective.description: Easy to mold, cut, compress, or fold; not hard or firm to the touch.
examples: the ground was soft beneath their feet

adjective.description: Having a pleasing quality involving a subtle effect or contrast rather than sharp definition.
examples: the soft glow of the lamps
the moon's pale light cast soft shadows

adjective.description: Sympathetic, lenient, or compassionate, especially to a degree perceived as excessive; not strict or sufficiently strict.
examples: the administration is not becoming soft on crime
Julia's soft heart was touched by his grief
all they had was ginger ale and a few other soft drinks

adjective.description: (of a market, currency, or commodity) falling or likely to fall in value.
(of water) containing relatively low concentrations of dissolved calcium and magnesium salts and therefore lathering easily with soap.
examples: you use only half as much soap when you clean with soft water
he must be going soft in the head

adjective.description: (of a consonant) pronounced as a fricative (as c in ice).

examples: I can just speak soft and she'll hear me

phrases: I have noticed that I have a soft spot for psychotic people.
Personally I've always had a soft spot for Liverpool, with my fond childhood memories of things like the Liver Birds and the Beatles.
The west coast of Scotland is renowned for having a soft spot for music with a country twang.
We've always had a soft spot for Kate, and are quite fond of Pete's work supporting Carl, but this is overplaying their hand to a dangerous extent.
I have rather a big soft spot for Jules, though, and I don't like seeing her upset.
origin: Old English sōfte agreeable, calm, gentle, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch zacht and German sanft.
